newsitem.title: UK: Some UK govt computers may not be ready for 2000.
newsitem.headline: Some UK govt computers may not be ready for 2000.

text.p: Only 80 percent of British government departments and agencies are confident of adapting their computers in time to avert the so-called millennium threat, the National Audit Office said on Wednesday.
It said the types of problems that could arise included salaries not being paid, police records being wiped out, tax collection being put at risk and defence systems malfunctioning.
The millennium threat stems from the possibility that some computer programmes, which express years as a double digit (currently 97), will be flummoxed by a double zero for 2000.
Some computers could simply shut down. Others could produce meaningless results if they assume that 00 comes before 99.

The NAO, an independent watchdog, said in a report that most of the government's information technology managers who responded to a recent survey were aware of the problem and were at the stage of auditing their systems.
But 20 percent were unable to say for sure that they would complete the work needed to guarantee that the wheels of government will keep turning in the year 2000.
"Where doubt was expressed about completion, the issues yet to be resolved were mainly about funding, resource availability, testing and compliance of bought-in products," the NAO said.

"There is a need for managers at all levels to be aware that this is not just a technical issue, but one which can have a profound impact on the ability of the organisation to continue functioning in the next millennium," the watchdog said.
The NAO said it was impossible for now to estimate the cost of tackling the problem.

"Although in most cases it is fairly simple to modify the way an information system stores dates, the number of modifications needed in most organisations makes this a huge programme to manage," it said.

Some experts have suggested large companies could face a bill of 10 million to 60 million pounds ($16 million to $98 million) each. The U.S. House of Representatives estimated that the cost of modifying the U.S. federal government's computer systems could reach $30 billion. ($1=.6098 Pound)
